channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Does nuclear secrecy make us more secure? New book offers counterargument
item.description: Historian Alex Wellerstein: “You could get rid of all the secrecy tomorrow and the world would not measurably become more dangerous.”

item.title: Leaks: May 21 will be the launch day for the new iMac, iPad Pro, and Apple TV
item.description: A prominent leaker, a UK retailer, and Apple itself all let the date slip.

item.title: Uber, Lyft stocks plunge after Biden official says drivers are employees
item.description: Uber and Lyft argue treating drivers as employees would wreck their business.

item.title: Today’s best deals: Lots of video games, rechargeable batteries, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Fitbit trackers and noise-canceling headphones.

item.title: FCC reveals sign-up date and website for $50-per-month broadband subsidies
item.description: May 12 enrollment for people who have low incomes or lost income during pandemic.

item.title: A Chinese company has started charging for fully driverless rides
item.description: China has the world’s strongest self-driving industry after the United States.

item.title: Brazil rejects Sputnik V vaccine, says it’s tainted with replicating cold virus
item.description: Adenovirus-vector vaccines are supposed to be engineered so they can’t replicate.

item.title: Microsoft follows Epic’s lead, lowers its cut of PC game sales to 12%
item.description: But the move may not be enough to dislodge heavily entrenched competition.

item.title: Conspiracy theorist said death threats were “jokes”—but jury didn’t buy it
item.description: Brendan Hunt posted videos about murdering US elected officials.

item.title: Want to save an island’s coral reefs? Get rid of invasive rats
item.description: Rats drive off birds, setting off a cascade of ecosystem damages that spread offshore.

item.title: Verizon tries to sell Yahoo and AOL after spending $9 billion on fallen giants
item.description: After spending $9 billion combined, Verizon may sell units for $4 billion or so.

item.title: You can now teach the Google Assistant how to pronounce names
item.description: Google can listen to you pronounce a name and learn from it.

item.title: Gas prices are expected to rise due to the truck driver shortage
item.description: Robotrucks aren’t here to save us yet.

item.title: Returnal review: Roguelite arcade combat has never felt this epic—or hard
item.description: Legendary dev Housemarque nails its most ambitious game yet, but beware its pitfalls.

item.title: This is the slightly sportier, slightly more efficient 2022 Honda Civic
item.description: The next Civic looks less like a starfighter, inside and out.

item.title: Facing uncharted waters, Apple reports 54% year-over-year revenue increase
item.description: Chip shortages and a waning pandemic might make growth unsustainable, though.

item.title: Office default Calibri will join Clippy, Internet Explorer in Windows retirement
item.description: “Calibri in Office” could almost drive (15 years old), but a new sans serif will soon emerge.

item.title: Verizon “leads” all US carriers in mmWave 5G availability at 0.8%
item.description: Phones capable of using mmWave 5G access it less than 1% of the time.

item.title: Algorithms were under fire at a Senate hearing on social media
item.description: “Algorithms have great potential for good. They can also be misused.”

item.title: Chipmaker says it will ramp up production of older 28nm chips
item.description: Fourth-largest contract chipmaker aiming at supply problems for carmakers, others.

item.title: Michael Collins, who piloted the Apollo 11 command module, has died
item.description: “The nation lost a true pioneer and lifelong advocate for exploration.”

item.title: Epic deposition shows how differently Google and Apple treat messaging
item.description: Apple considered fighting a Google/WhatsApp acquisition with iMessage on Android.

item.title: Play this Dreamcast Castlevania game 20+ years after it was canceled
item.description: Castlevania: Resurrection was briefly seen at E3 1999, then vanished for decades.

item.title: Toyota is entering a hydrogen-powered Corolla in a 24-hour race
item.description: It’s still internal combustion, not a fuel cell.

item.title: SitRep: Is the F-35 officially a failure?
item.description: Cost overruns, other issues prompt Air Force to look for “clean sheet” fighter.

item.title: These concept interiors for an electric Lexus are thought-provoking
item.description: Untreated leather, translucent silicone cushions, and granite steering wheels.

item.title: New Pokémon Snap is a welcome take on the “first-person shooter”
item.description: Plenty of secrets and adorable moments make for the perfect relaxation game.

item.title: Ransomware crooks threaten to ID informants if cops don’t pay up
item.description: The FBI is investigating claim hackers obtained 250GB of police department data.

item.title: Nestlé threatened with cease-and-desist over alleged illegal water use
item.description: Company’s claims hinge on how much water early-1900s rail cars carried.

item.title: High-bandwidth wireless BCI demonstrated in humans for first time
item.description: BrainGate device complements Neuralink’s successful test of wireless BCI in monkey.

item.title: Lyft is getting out of the self-driving business
item.description: Lyft will save about $100 million without its self-driving project.

item.title: FCC lets SpaceX cut satellite altitude to improve Starlink speed and latency
item.description: Rival satellite companies opposed change that cuts altitude in half, to 540 km.

item.title: To entice vaccine-hesitant, Biden touts maskless activities for vaccinated
item.description: Biden: “This is another great reason to go get vaccinated—now, now.”

item.title: Report: Apple’s M2 chip has entered production and will ship as soon as July
item.description: The timeline in this report suggests new Macs might be introduced at WWDC.

item.title: Today’s best deals: Sony noise-canceling headphones, Fitbit trackers, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on the latest Super Mario game and Echo Dot speaker.

item.title: Contractor that ruined 15M doses of J&J vaccine is holding up vaccine to India
item.description: India is in crisis, but US can’t yet ship stockpiled AstraZeneca vaccine doses.

item.title: CentOS replacement distro AlmaLinux gets commercial support options
item.description: This CentOS replacement seems to be “getting there firstest with the mostest.”

item.title: Amazon’s 11th-gen Fire HD 10 tablet starts at $149.99
item.description: There’s a Plus and non-Plus model, two kids' versions, a keyboard, a charging dock…

item.title: Tesla posts another record quarterly profit—and Wall Street shrugs
item.description: Tesla has $17 billion in the bank.

item.title: Cable-chewing beavers take out town’s Internet in “uniquely Canadian” outage
item.description: Beavers dug 3-foot hole, chewed through fiber conduit and the cable itself.

item.title: Ford is setting up a new EV battery center in southeast Michigan
item.description: It will be called Ion Park and will work with Ford’s Allen Park test lab.

item.title: EU to charge Apple with anticompetitive behavior this week
item.description: Case began two years ago and is one of several involving the iPhone maker.

item.title: Archaeologists found the site of Harriet Tubman’s family home
item.description: The site was found on federal land recently acquired for marshland conservation.

item.title: A freshly flush Lotus Cars readies four new vehicle architectures
item.description: The next Lotus will also be the last one to use internal combustion engines.

item.title: Actively exploited Mac 0-day neutered core OS security defenses
item.description: Apple fixes macOS vulnerability hackers exploited to suppress security warnings.

item.title: Legislation would mandate driver-monitoring tech in every car
item.description: Distracted driving claimed more than 3,000 lives in the US in 2019.

item.title: Linux kernel team rejects University of Minnesota researchers’ apology
item.description: UMN researchers probed for weaknesses in patch approval—Greg K-H wasn’t amused.

item.title: Apple releases iOS 14.5, the biggest update since iOS 14 first launched
item.description: Read for screenshots, update notes, and changes aplenty.

item.title: Pentagon explains odd transfer of 175 million IP addresses to obscure company
item.description: Something weird happened minutes before Trump left—US says it was security research.

item.title: Bad infrastructure and not being male among reasons people give up EVs
item.description: About 20 percent of Californian EV adopters gave up plug-ins, study finds.

item.title: New versions of macOS, watchOS, and tvOS hit supported devices today
item.description: macOS gets improved iPhone/iPad app experiences, AirTag support, and more.

item.title: It took Facebook two months to realize “Stop the Steal” might turn violent
item.description: Social media giant was apparently unprepared for “authentic” calls for violence.

item.title: Believe the hype: The Hyundai Veloster N is a darn good hot hatch
item.description: Tired of Europe getting great hatches we don’t? Now the tables have turned.

item.title: Africa’s first Iron Age culture had a sweet tooth
item.description: The results offer some of the oldest physical evidence of honey in people’s diets.

item.title: Roku warns customers: “Google may remove your access to YouTube TV” [Updated]
item.description: Roku says Google wants changes to Roku search. Google calls the claims “baseless.”

item.title: No, this strange Twitter account isn’t teasing a new Metal Gear Solid [Updated]
item.description: The strange story of @TheTomOlsen, “Maintenance Technician at the Big Shell.”

item.title: China’s state rocket company unveils rendering of a Starship look-alike
item.description: The Asian country has tracked SpaceX from the beginning.

item.title: Review: The Falcon and the Winter Soldier aims high but falls a bit short
item.description: It tries to do too many things at once, and thus doesn’t do them as well as it could.

item.title: Children of Chernobyl cleanup crew don’t have excess mutations
item.description: A deep look into the genetic damage left by the disaster.

item.title: Why lawmakers are so interested in Apple’s and Google’s “rents”
item.description: You can’t understand the app store debate without some grasp of antitrust jargon.
